description: From Ancient Greek χιτών (khitṓn, “tunic”), from a Central Semitic *kittan, from the Akkadian 𒌆𒃰 (kitû, literally “flax, linen”), from Sumerian 𒄑𒃰 (kitû [GIŠ.GADA]).

entries.meaning: (historical) A loose woolen tunic worn by men and women in Ancient Greece.
examples: She wears a diaphanous himation that covers her torso, over a floor-length chiton of heavier fabric.

description: From New Latin chiton. See above.

entries.meaning: Any of various rock-clinging marine molluscs of the class Polyplacophora, including the genus Chiton.
